Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 11:03AM - edited Sep 18, 2009 11:04AM by Juli-CA Christine I self inject my Neupogen shots for seven days every cycle.  I begin on day three.  This helps to boost the production of the white blood cells.  I haven't felt any bone pain as others feel with Neulasta, which is a once a cycle shot.   I'm on TCH x 6 every three weeks.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 07:38AM - edited Sep 6, 2009 06:55PM by Juli-CA I'm new here and appreciate all of your posts.  Here's where I am:  lumpectomy on July 14, ER+, PR-, HER2+, IDC 1.4 cm, stage 1, grade 3.  I started chemo TCH on Aug. 18 (four days after my son's wedding) every 3 weeks for 6 cycles.  I'll be on Herceptin for a total of one year. I attended a chemo information class two weeks before the beginning of treatment which was very helpful in preparing me and calming me down.  What I learned:  Water: two quarts a day beginning the day before the first treatment.  Take all meds for nausea as directed BEFORE you feel queasy.  Be prepared for hair loss, those receiving Taxotere lose their hair 98% of the time.  So I bought a wig and sewed some head coverings.   Two weeks to the day, my hair started thinning so I had it cut short.  Four days later, that's today, it is very thin.  One thing I did buy ahead of time was a head covering to wear at night so that when the hair is falling out, it doesn't get all over the pillow from  www.tlcdirect.org   When it started to come out, my scalp felt slightly sensitive, as if I had combed my hair one way for so long and then tried to comb it the opposite direction.  I think that I will just shave it off after church tomorrow and get it over with.   So after my first chemo, I felt like a time bomb.  I didn't know if or when the side effects would occur.  I didn't feel anything until day three and that was some fatigue.  By day 6, I needed to say close to the bathroom.  Day 7 tired but OK and dizzy in the evening.  Early on day 8 vomiting, fever and tired.  Off the the ER as the doc said anything over 100.5 means trouble.  I was admitted for two days and two nights and given IV antibiotics.  I must have picked up some virus because all of the blood cultures came back negative.  Some might think this would make me more apprehensive about the next treatment, I figure that I came through this and survived so I am tough enough!  Funny thing, that first night in the hospital, I slept like a log, hadn't slept that well since the diagnosis!  Must have been too rung out from being sick. I have signed up the for Look Good Feel Better class right at the medical center where I receive infusions.  I am really looking forward to that. Next treatment is on Tuesday the 8th.  Juli
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2009 07:07PM - edited Sep 6, 2009 07:21PM by Juli-CA Lottie, I am on Taxotere and Carboplatin.  I think that the Carboplatin is in the same family as Cytoxan or it is the same drug with different name. I don't know if it is a "dense" dosage or what.  Someone will need to define that for me.  I'll ask at the next treatment.  My hat goes off to those of you who are working through your treatments.  I just can't imagine feeling crumby and still be at work.  I was not working when I was diagnosed just attending community college and working on an accounting degree.  No school for me this fall.  Between staying away from people during flu season and the mention of "chemo brain" I decided to take a semester off.   I think that the suggestion to exercise is excellent.  Probably not at much as before treatment but it does keep my energy level up to get out and walk in the neighborhood.  It has been fun to try different sun hats too.    --Juli
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2009 06:56PM - edited Sep 7, 2009 07:31PM by Juli-CA Chinablue, From all that I have read and been told by my doctors and nurses, avoid caffeine completely but drink 2 quarts of water each day.  After my first chemo on Aug. 18, I lost weight.  Don't know if that is normal but I have been advised to be careful not to lose too much weight so that my body won't be stressed by that as well as the chemo.  The other thing I was advised by the onc and rad MD is to limit  anti-oxidant pill supplements.  The chemo process is an oxidation process on the cancer cells and you don't want your body's chemistry getting in the way of that process.  I was told that if you are eating foods that contain anti-oxitents that's fine, you won't get too much from food. Lisa, I'll ROAR with you!  Thanks for sharing your great attitude. I agree that all of the new ladies should read this thread from the beginning as there is valuable information there.  Also, the whole forum is fantastic.  I especially found the chemo bag a great help.  It is detailed in this thread:  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/478386 Juli
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 08:54PM - edited Sep 17, 2009 08:57PM by Juli-CA I have not posted here for several days but I have been reading.  Maybe I can add a few things.  I'm on day 9 of my second cycle of TCH.  My energy is back and I felt good enough to do some early Christmas shopping.  Wow, how good it felt to feel good! Decadron-it makes me sort of hyper which is fine during the day.  I take it the day before chemo and for three more days but it keeps me awake the night of the first day so I end up taking a sleeping pill.  I feel like I'm chasing  so many drug side effects with more drugs but I won't complain because it keeps the nausea away.  I haven't noticed any weight gain from the decadron.  Wig-I ordered two from TLC before my hair started falling out.  I have a large head so I was pleased that their wigs are sized.  I really like one of the wigs and it looks good on.  The other I will donate to my local ACS wig room so someone can use it.  I also ordered the lightweight night cap that catches your hair as it falls out so you don't have a pillow covered with hair in the morning.  It isn't pretty but it works well.  Hair- mine started falling out 14 days after the first chemo tx and I had it cut short that day: just a bob.  Seven days later, it was so thin I cut it close to the scalp.  That was not easy but my husband of 30 years shaved his mustache for the first time.  That's right, I have never seen him without it until now.  It was a fair trade. LGFB- attend this class on Monday and really enjoyed the experience.  Great volunteers and a nice group of ladies in various stages of chemo.  One has her hair back but told stories of having her wig blow off in the Target parking lot and having to chase it across the lot as the wind blew and it blew off in the car to the back seat when the window was down.  We need to laugh and not cry during some of our adventures. Juli
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 12:44AM Juli-CA wrote: Sure do enjoy all of your comments and suggestions.  Reading this gave me the courage to color my hair this week.  Pre-chemo I was a bottle brunette due to early gray hair (at 52 I'm still not ready to be gray), so the post-chemo hair is not the color I care to be seen wearing!  There's about an inch plus of hair growth and have been leary about how soon to color so that I don't  damage what hair I have.  Used Clairol Natural Instinct since it is a semi temp and not as harsh as the totally permanent.  Using medium brown, it came out light brown because the gray is so hard to color but I LOVE IT!  No more gray!!!  I just might go without the wig once or twice this week. Juli
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 10:02PM - edited Feb 2, 2010 10:04PM by Juli-CA Lottie- I finished TCH X 6 with the last treatment on Dec. 1.  My eyebrows thinned but never left completely.  As for my eyelashes, I was left with about thee on each line of lashes.  The brows have begun to grow and I shaved my legs for the first time yesterday. I am with you on the watering eyes.  Mine have done the same as you have described and there are days they stream down along the side of my nose.  It has not resolved itself so when I see my onc. tomorrow, I'll him ask for solutions.  I have read about the tubes and I hope that will work for you. My hair is about 1/2 inch long and very salt and pepper colored.  My "natural" color was medium brown so when I started to turn gray, I colored it.  I'm 51 and a grandmother now but I still think I'll color it again. Juli
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2010 12:04AM - edited Apr 7, 2010 12:07AM by Juli-CA A BIG THANK YOU to you for posting photos of your hair growth.  It is soooo good to be with others with the same hair style!  I would post a photo too if I could figure out the process.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2010 02:40AM - edited Feb 5, 2010 02:41AM by Juli-CA RE:  Where is the hair growing? My last TCH was Dec. 1.  I noticed my head hair began to grow before any other place and is now about 1/2 inch long.  The second place goes to the leg hair.  No hair under the arms yet but I don't mind.  The south land is still sparse with no noticeable regrowth yet.  I can't wait to color the head hair!  It is very gray with a few dark brown hairs widely scatted. ccbaby- thanks for the photos.  They give me hope for my future hair style. Juli
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2010 11:42PM - edited Feb 15, 2010 10:09PM by Juli-CA Charmaine-  My last chemo was Dec. 1 so I have about 1/2" of growth.  The sides are fine growing down but the top is odd.  The top left is growing out sideways toward the right and about 3/4 of the way across it meets with the top right side and which creates a peak or short mohawk!  If that is the definition of "pointed" then you are not the only one.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2010 02:29AM Juli-CA wrote: RE: peach fuzz.  I shaved the peach fuzz last month and again this month.  It does come back with some stubble but it's white/clear and does not show. My hair is about an inch long and covers my scalp.  The sides are straight but the top seems to be growing in swirls.  Very odd. Before chemo, I colored my hair for 10 years to cover the gray so no one knows me with anything but brown hair.  Now the natural color is mostly salt with some pepper and I do not intend for anyone to see it that way! Since I have several good looking wigs from  tlcdirct.org that's what the outside world sees.(I like the wig liner from TLC too)  At home, I don't wear a wig as they are too warm for me.  Last weekend my husband was taking me to dinner in San Francisco for my birthday.  It had been a busy Saturday running errands and such so when it was time to leave, I changed clothes, grabbed my purse and we headed out the door.  We were down the street when I reached up to scratch my head and noticed I didn't have my wig on!  I told my husband to turn around so that I could go back for it.  He said he had noticed I didn't have it on and thought I looked fine and since I would not see anyone I knew that night, what better place to go without a head cover,  So off we went and had a nice dinner.  DH refers to it as my coming out party with him as the only guest. Juli
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53
